title-group.article-title: Exome Sequencing of Familial Bipolar Disorder

contrib-group.aff: Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, Baltimore, Maryland (Goes, Pirooznia); Stanley Institute for Cognitive Genomics, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, New York (Parla, Kramer, Ghiban, Mavruk, McCombie); Department of Biomedical Engineering, The Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Maryland (Chen, Karchin); Institute for Computational Medicine, The Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Maryland (Chen, Karchin); Department of Psychiatry, Carver College of Medicine, University of Iowa, Iowa City (Monson, Willour, Potash); Department of Biostatistics and Center for Statistical Genetics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor (Flickinger, Locke, Scott, Boehnke); HudsonAlpha Institute of Biotechnology, Huntsville, Alabama (Levy); Division of Psychiatric Genomics, Department of Psychiatry, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, New York, New York (Stahl, Purcell, Sklar); Institute for Genomics and Multiscale Biology, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, New York, New York (Stahl, Purcell, Sklar); Stanley Center for Psychiatric Research, Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, Cambridge, Massachusetts (Moran, Purcell); Department of Medical Epidemiology and Biostatistics, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden (Hultman, Landén); Institute of Neuroscience and Physiology, University of Gothenburg, Gothenburg, Sweden (Landén); Medical and Population Genetics Program, Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, Cambridge, Massachusetts (Purcell); Analytic and Translational Genetics Unit, Psychiatric and Neurodevelopmental Genetics Unit, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston (Purcell); Friedman Brain Institute, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, New York, New York (Sklar); Department of Mental Health, Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, Baltimore, Maryland (Zandi).

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Fernando S. Goes, MD, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, The Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, Meyer 4-119A, 600 N Wolfe St, Baltimore, MD 21287 (fgoes1@jhmi.edu)

fn.p: Conflict of Interest Disclosures: No other disclosures were reported.

sec.title: IMPORTANCE
sec.p: Complex disorders, such as bipolar disorder (BD), likely result from the influence of both common and rare susceptibility alleles. While common variation has been widely studied, rare variant discovery has only recently become feasible with next-generation sequencing.

sec.title: OBJECTIVE
sec.p: To utilize a combined family-based and case-control approach to exome sequencing in BD using multiplex families as an initial discovery strategy, followed by association testing in a large case-control meta-analysis.

sec.title: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS
sec.p: We performed exome sequencing of 36 affected members with BD from 8 multiplex families and tested rare, segregating variants in 3 independent case-control samples consisting of 3541 BD cases and 4774 controls.

sec.title: MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES
sec.p: We used penalized logistic regression and 1-sided gene-burden analyses to test for association of rare, segregating damaging variants with BD. Permutation-based analyses were performed to test for overall enrichment with previously identified gene sets.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: We found 84 rare (frequency <1%), segregating variants that were bioinformatically predicted to be damaging. These variants were found in 82 genes that were enriched for gene sets previously identified in de novo studies of autism (19 observed vs. 10.9 expected, P = .0066) and schizophrenia (11 observed vs. 5.1 expected, P = .0062) and for targets of the fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP) pathway (10 observed vs. 4.4 expected, P = .0076). The case-control meta-analyses yielded 19 genes that were nominally associated with BD based either on individual variants or a gene-burden approach. Although no gene was individually significant after correction for multiple testing, this group of genes continued to show evidence for significant enrichment of de novo autism genes (6 observed vs 2.6 expected, P = .028).

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE
sec.p: Our results are consistent with the presence of prominent locus and allelic heterogeneity in BD and suggest that very large samples will be required to definitively identify individual rare variants or genes conferring risk for this disorder. However, we also identify significant associations with gene sets composed of previously discovered de novo variants in autism and schizophrenia, as well as targets of the FRMP pathway, providing preliminary support for the overlap of potential autism and schizophrenia risk genes with rare, segregating variants in families with BD.
